title: Heerenveen
text:
Heerenveen (, ) is a <a href="town">town</a> and <a href="municipality">municipality</a> in the province of <a href="Friesland">Friesland</a> (Fryslân), in the north of the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>. 
History.
The town was established in 1551 by three lords as a location for the purpose of digging <a href="peat">peat</a> which was used for fuel, hence the name ("heer" is "lord", "veen" is "peat"). Heerenveen was not one of the traditional eleven cities in <a href="Friesland">Friesland</a> (Fryslân) as it did not have so-called <a href="City%20rights%20in%20the%20Low%20Countries">city rights</a>. However, it is now one of the larger municipalities of the province.
The <a href="windmill">windmill</a> <a href="Welgelegen%2C%20Heerenveen">"Welgelegen" or "Tjepkema's Molen"</a> is the only survivor of seventeen which have stood in Heerenveen.
Population centres.
Population as of 1 January 2018:
Heerenveen (32,900), <a href="Akkrum">Akkrum</a> (3406), <a href="Aldeboarn">Aldeboarn</a> (1479), <a href="Bontebok%2C%20Heerenveen">Bontebok</a> (445), <a href="De%20Knipe">De Knipe</a> (1470), <a href="Gersloot">Gersloot</a> (280, together with <a href="Gersloot-Polder">Gersloot-Polder</a>), <a href="Hoornsterzwaag">Hoornsterzwaag</a> (815), <a href="Jubbega">Jubbega</a> (3510), <a href="Katlijk">Katlijk</a> (630), <a href="Luinjeberd">Luinjeberd</a> (450), <a href="Mildam">Mildam</a> (740), <a href="Nes%2C%20Heerenveen">Nes</a> (1104), <a href="Nieuwebrug%2C%20Friesland">Nieuwebrug</a> (210), <a href="Nieuwehorne">Nieuwehorne</a> (1500), <a href="Nieuweschoot">Nieuweschoot</a> (180), <a href="Oranjewoud">Oranjewoud</a> (1610), <a href="Oudehorne">Oudehorne</a> (840), <a href="Oudeschoot">Oudeschoot</a> (1480), <a href="Terband">Terband</a> (265) and <a href="Tjalleberd">Tjalleberd</a> (800).
Hamlets.
The hamlets are: <a href="Anneburen">Anneburen</a>, <a href="Birstum">Birstum</a>, <a href="Brongergea">Brongergea</a>, <a href="Easterboarn">Easterboarn</a>, <a href="Jinshuzen">Jinshuzen</a>, <a href="Meskenwier">Meskenwier</a>, <a href="Oude%20Schouw">Oude Schouw</a> (partially), <a href="Pean%2C%20Netherlands">Pean</a>, <a href="Poppenh%C3%BAzen">Poppenhúzen</a>, <a href="Schurega">Schurega</a>, <a href="Soarremoarre">Soarremoarre</a>, <a href="Spitsendijk">Spitsendijk</a>, <a href="Sythuzen">Sythuzen</a>, <a href="Warniah%C3%BAzen">Warniahúzen</a> en <a href="Welgelegen%2C%20hamlet">Welgelegen</a> (partially).
Transport.
Railway station: <a href="Heerenveen%20railway%20station">Heerenveen</a>
Sports.
Heerenveen is famous for its sporting accomplishments and world class sports accommodations. These include the <a href="Abe%20Lenstra%20Stadion">Abe Lenstra football stadium</a> and the <a href="Thialf">Thialf</a> <a href="speed%20skating">speed skating</a> <a href="arena">arena</a> which was one of the first indoor 400m ice rinks in the world, and where annually held international events draw large crowds. Thialf is also home to the city's ice hockey team, the <a href="Heerenveen%20Flyers">Heerenveen Flyers</a>.
The town's <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> team, <a href="SC%20Heerenveen">SC Heerenveen</a>, plays in the first tier and has been a steady presence in the <a href="Europa%20League">Europa League</a>, topped by the team's biggest achievement when they qualified for the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> in 2000.
In 2006, the "Sportstad" (Sport City) project was completed, which included a gymnastics hall, swimming pool and an extension to the football stadium, all of which are clustered together. The Abe Lenstra stadium is unusual because its supporter capacity is larger than the number of inhabitants of the town. One of the few football venues that shares this distinction is <a href="Stade%20F%C3%A9lix%20Bollaert">Stade Félix Bollaert</a> in <a href="Lens%2C%20Pas-de-Calais">Lens</a>, <a href="France">France</a>. Several <a href="American%20football">American football</a> venues, mostly <a href="college%20football">college football</a> venues, also share this distinction.
Twin cities.
Heereveen's longstanding connection with <a href="Rishon%20LeZion">Rishon LeZion</a> ended in 2016 after the supporting organizations shut down in both countries.
